headline: Pesto alla Trapanese (Sicilian Pesto With Almonds and Tomatoes) Recipe
description: Pesto alla trapanese is Sicily's answer to Liguria's more famous basil-rich pesto sauce. They have a lot in common, as both are full of fresh basil, nuts, garlic, olive oil, and cheese, and are best mixed with a mortar and pestle. Trapanese pesto uses almonds instead of pine nuts, and adds juicy tomatoes to the mix.
name: Pesto alla Trapanese (Sicilian Pesto With Almonds and Tomatoes) Recipe
keywords: easy, Italian, mortar and pestle, pasta, pesto, quick, sauce, sicilian, tomato
recipeIngredient: 2 ounces toasted blanched almonds (60g; about 1/2 cup); see note
35 large basil leaves (about 4 sprigs, weighing 25g total)
3 1/2 ounces (100g) grated cheese, preferably a milder aged pecorino or a 50/50 mix of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano, plus more for serving
1 pound (450g) plum tomatoes, peeled and seeded
1/4 cup (60ml) extra-virgin olive oil, plus more as needed

recipeInstructions.text: If Using a Mortar and Pestle: Crush the garlic in the mortar with a pinch of salt to form a paste. Add almonds and beat and crush into a rough paste. Work in basil leaves and mint (if using), pounding and crushing into tiny bits. Smash in cheese, followed by tomatoes and olive oil. The final sauce should be a rough paste. Season with salt.
If Using a Food Processor: Pulse garlic with almonds until roughly chopped. Add basil, mint (if using), cheese, tomatoes, and olive oil and process to a rough paste. Season with salt.
Transfer 2/3 of the sauce to a large heatproof serving bowl.

In a pot of salted boiling water, cook linguine until al dente. Transfer pasta to serving bowl, reserving some of the pasta-cooking water. Toss well, adding more olive oil and pasta-cooking water, one tablespoon at a time each, until a creamy sauce forms that's not dry but also not soupy. Season with salt, if needed. If the sauce gets too dry at any point, simply add more pasta-cooking water to loosen it.
Serve, spooning remaining sauce on top of each portion and adding more cheese as desired.

review.reviewBody: With some elbow grease, made this amazing pesto using a tiny mortar and pestle. Had a bunch of cherry tomatoes and ended up using skin and seeds too, out of convenience. The pesto turned out delicious, could eat it alone, raw. Had it over fresh homemade pasta with squid ink and tomato skin dust. Eating pasta out became, once again, obsolete. Thanks, Daniel, for the amazing recipe!

We made this one tonight by the recipe (no mint, though), mortar and pestle. It's DELICIOUS. The mortar and pestle is a pain, but the extra effort is worth it when you're using great ingredients. Loved how the tomatoes lightened everything up . . . we love Ligurian pesto but this might be our new favorite.
Holy cow this is amazing. Skipped the mint, used some San Marzanos that I grew and tossed it with orecchiette. Absolutely wonderful!
Just made this with toasted/skinned hazelnuts & it's terrific, but I've never had it before so I have nothing to judge it against.

@Dawn007 yes, I did and it worked very well. I used both canned chopped tomatoes and canned whole plum tomatoes. The plum tomatoes I chopped into quarters myself. I put the tomatoes in a sieve and pressed with the back of a spoon until they looked dry enough. Then they went into the food processor. The seeds were no problem.
